answers: Look up at the sky on Jan. 31 and you may witness a sight unseen for 150 years. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)

pred: The US ambassador to Syria, Robert Ford, visited Hama on Thursday to demonstrate support for the people of the city who are advocating for democracy. The visit came after a series of peaceful demonstrations in Hama, which saw hundreds of thousands of people demonstrating against the government's crackdown on dissent. The US embassy notified the Syrian government that an embassy delegation was traveling to Hama, but the Syrian government denied any involvement in the trip. The US State Department stated that Ford's visit was intended to show support for the people of Hama and to emphasize the importance of the US's stance on the situation in Syria. The US embassy warned that the visit could cause further unrest in Hama, and the Syrian government has accused the US of interfering in its affairs. The US embassy in Hama has been ordered to leave the city without permission, and the US state department has summoned the ambassador to meet with senior officials to discuss concerns about the actions of certain US embassy staff in Syria. The US has also issued warnings of violence in other parts of Syria, including the towns of Hama and Hasrat, where at least 23 civilians have died and security forces have carried out mass arrests and killings. The US has been supporting the people of Hama and other cities in Syria through diplomatic efforts, including the visit of the US ambassador to Hama. However, the Syrian government has denied any involvement in the visit or the US's intentions. The US and Syrian governments continue to face challenges in maintaining peace and stability in Syria, with the ongoing conflict causing widespread violence and displacement.
answers: America's ambassador to Syria visited one of the cities worst-hit by the crackdown against anti-government protesters yesterday, reports CNN. Robert Ford went to the city of Hama "to make absolutely clear with his physical presence that we stand with those Syrians who are expressing their right to speak for change," an embassy spokeswoman says. An estimated 500,000 people joined an anti-government rally in the city last Friday. The Syrian government accused Ford of going to the city without authorization, saying the visit is "clear evidence of the US involvement in the ongoing events in Syria and its bids to aggravate the situations which destabilize Syria.'' An embassy spokeswoman says the Syrian government was told a delegation would be visiting Hama, although no Syrian "handlers" were taken and officials weren't informed about the ambassador's presence. The city has been a symbol of opposition since 1982, when a crackdown ordered by the present Syrian leader's father killed around 20,000 people, al-Jazeera notes.

pred: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is investigating a cyberattack on the Democratic National Committee (DNC), which is considered the most sensitive information in the US election cycle. The investigation involves multiple elements, including the use of social media, the manipulation of voter registration data, and attempts to infiltrate the organization through various means. The FBI has stated that the attack was a "simulated phishing test," indicating that the hackers were attempting to gain access to the party's voter database through a fake login page. The DNC reported receiving alerts from the cloud service provider and security research firm, who discovered the malicious page in the early hours of Tuesday morning. The DNC believes that the attackers used the page to collect usernames and passwords, which could be used to manipulate votes during the upcoming midterms. The FBI and the two security firms involved have confirmed that they successfully thwarted the attempted hack, preventing any unauthorized access to the DNC's voter database. The incident highlights the increasing threat of cyberattacks in the US election cycle and the importance of maintaining robust cybersecurity measures to protect sensitive information.
answers: The FBI is reportedly investigating a sophisticated—but unsuccessful—attempt to hack into the Democratic National Committee's voter database. The DNC learned of the attempt on Tuesday, CNN reports. The attack, which was detected by a cloud service provider and a security research company, involved a fake login page intended to gather usernames and passwords for a service called Votebuilder, which hosts the DNC's voter database. It's a method called "spearphishing," according to the New York Times. "It was very convincing," Mike Murray of the cybersecurity firm Lookout tells CNN, adding that it would be tough to tell the real page from the fake one, even if they were side-by-side. The fake login page was ultimately removed by the cloud hosting company DigitalOcean. The company's chief security officer says the threat was identified before the attack was launched. "We see no evidence that any sensitive data was stolen," he says. A DNC official tells the Times that it is not clear who the hackers were in this case. But, the paper recalls, a 2016 hack of the DNC was ultimately traced to Russia. This latest attempt, DNC Chief Security Officer Bob Lord tells the Times, "is further proof that there are constant threats as we head into midterm elections and we must remain vigilant in order to prevent future attacks." Earlier this week, Microsoft reported that it had uncovered new Russian hacking attempts targeting conservative organizations in the US.

pred: The Boston Marathon was hit by two explosions, killing two people and leaving hundreds of mourners gathered to pay tribute to the victims. The first victim, 8-year-old Martin Richard, was identified as a member of the Chinese Consulate in Boston, while the second victim, 29-year-old Krystle Campbell, was found dead at the finish line of the marathon. The Chinese Consulate in New York confirmed the student's death, and the university didn't release the student's name or gender, pending family permission. The police and the federal government have increased security measures at bus and airport stations and announced that they will "go to the ends of the earth" to find anyone responsible for the attacks. The Boston community has come together to mourn the loss of the victims and support each other. The city is still grappling with the identity of the deceased and the investigation into the cause of the explosions. The police and the FBI are actively searching for any additional threats and are working closely with the community to ensure the safety of the city. The city is determined to move forward and rebuild, acknowledging the tragedy as a reminder of the resilience and unity of the Boston community.
answers: Another fatality in the Boston bombings has been identified: The family of 29-year-old Krystle Campbell says she was killed as she and a friend were cheering on another friend who was racing, reports WCVB. "This is just a waste," says her mother. “Everyone that knew her loved her. She was always smiling. You couldn’t ask for a better daughter. She was the best.” Campbell was a restaurant manager, reports the Boston Herald, which notes an especially wrenching detail: Her father was initially told she was alive, but when he got to the ICU, he realized it was his daughter's friend who had survived. Campbell is the second of the three people killed to be identified. The first was 8-year-old Martin Richard, and his father, Bill, released a statement today thanking supporters and asking for privacy, reports WBZ. "My dear son Martin has died from injuries sustained in the attack on Boston. My wife and daughter are both recovering from serious injuries. We thank our family and friends, those we know and those we have never met, for their thoughts and prayers. I ask that you continue to pray for my family as we remember Martin. We also ask for your patience and for privacy as we work to simultaneously grieve and recover. Thank you." The third victim was a grad student at Boston University, but the person's identity is being withheld until the family says it's OK to release, reports USA Today.

pred: The article discusses the alarming trend of obesity, which affects millions of people worldwide, accounting for 2.1 billion people, or 13% of the global population, according to a new study published in the Lancet. The study, titled "World Obesity Report," provides a comprehensive overview of obesity trends over the past three decades, revealing that obesity rates have risen across all regions, including the USA, where obesity rates exceed 5%, and even more in developing countries. The study highlights the increasing prevalence of obesity among men, women, and children, with women and children experiencing particularly high rates of obesity in some countries. The study also finds that obesity rates are rising in both developed and developing countries, with obesity rates in the Middle East and North Africa reaching staggering levels, while obesity rates in the US are still relatively low despite a significant increase in obesity rates in developing countries. The study identifies several factors contributing to obesity, including increased consumption of unhealthy foods, reduced physical activity, and changes in the gut microbiome in modern times. The study concludes that obesity is a major risk factor for chronic diseases such as heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and cancer, affecting approximately 3.4 million adults per year, and 22% of the world's population is affected by obesity. The report emphasizes the need for addressing obesity through a combination of lifestyle changes, improved diets, and access to healthy food options, as well as the potential role of socioeconomic factors in shaping obesity rates. The study suggests that obesity is a global issue that affects not only wealthy countries but also developing ones, highlighting the importance of reducing obesity rates in all regions. The report calls for a comprehensive approach to address obesity, including the World Health Organization's launch of a commission to study rising obesity worldwide, which aims to identify and recommend solutions to improve public health outcomes. The study underscores the significance of obesity in relation to economic growth, with obesity rates rising alongside population growth, and the need to address obesity as a major public health concern.
answers: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. The 188-country study found that there are 2.1 billion overweight or obese people in the world, making up around 30% of the world's population, up from 20% in 1980, USA Today reports. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." The study published in British medical journal the Lancet found that the Middle East and north Africa had seen the biggest weight gains, though the US still has the largest number of obese people, with 87 million of the world's 671 million obese people, reports Reuters. Other countries, however, have even higher obesity rates, including Tonga, where more than 50% of all adults are obese. "Two-thirds of the obese population actually resides in developing countries," says one of the researchers; they warn that obesity rates are rising among rich and poor countries, men and women, and adults and children alike.

pred: The three news articles cover various aspects of the relationship between Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, including the recent emotional reunion letter he wrote to her after their divorce. The article also mentions that Cruise and Holmes have not spoken to each other in over a year, and sources close to the couple claim that the letter has had a positive impact on Holmes, who has been moved by Cruise's thoughtfulness and desire to reconnect with her. answers: It's been a year since Katie Holmes filed for divorce from Tom Cruise, and apparently Cruise is feeling sentimental. A source tells UK magazine Look the actor sent Holmes an "emotional letter" looking to, at the very least, be friends again, Australia's News Network reports. "It's like he's finally recognized that Katie will always be the love of his life," the source says. Even so, "It won't have been an over the top letter—it has been a year and I'm sure Tom will have been aware that Katie wouldn't be interested in running straight back into his arms." Sources close to Holmes say she was "touched" by the letter, which doesn't sound promising for Cruise. "Tom would no doubt take her back in a second, but I don't think that's what Katie wants," says one. (Just to keep things in perspective, we'll point out that Look is the sort of magazine that also runs headlines like, "Royal Bodyguard Warns: 'Kate Middleton's Baby Is In Danger!'") pred: The deaths of two wealthy Canadian pharmaceutical giants, Barry Sherman and Honey Sherman, were ruled suspicious by the Toronto police, who found their bodies hanging from a rail fence in their Toronto mansion. The couple's deaths were initially classified as a "suspicious" homicide, but the police have now confirmed that the deaths were indeed suicides due to a ligature neck compression. The couple's deaths have raised questions about the circumstances surrounding their deaths and the possibility of a murder-suicide. A makeshift memorial was set up in their honor, and friends and colleagues of the couple expressed shock and disbelief at the tragedy. The couple had four children and had recently welcomed a grandchild, and their net worth was estimated to be $4.77 billion. The couple was known for their philanthropy and charitable work, particularly in the areas of healthcare and education. They were planning a dinner party with a number of Toronto friends at their winter home in Palm Beach, where they were found in a buoyant mood on October 28, and their final moments were described as "more outgoing" and "euphoric." The couple was found dead in their home on Friday, and their bodies were removed from the house by a police officer. The police have stated that there was no evidence of forced entry or any indication of a murder-suicide, but the investigation remains ongoing. The couple's deaths have shocked the local community and raised questions about the circumstances surrounding their deaths.
answers: The investigation into the mysterious deaths of a billionaire and his wife is now being led by homicide detectives, police say—suggesting the deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman were either murder-suicide or a double murder. Police, who have described the deaths as "suspicious," revealed Sunday that the cause of death for both Shermans was "ligature neck compression," a form of strangulation, the CBC reports. Sources have told the media that the couple were found hanging near an indoor pool in the basement of their Toronto mansion. Police say they haven't found any sign of forced entry, or a note that could explain what happened to 75-year-old pharmaceutical tycoon Barry Sherman and his 70-year-old wife, both renowned philanthropists. The couple's four children have rejected what they say are "rumors" that the deaths are being investigated as a murder-suicide, and many of the influential couple's friends agree. "There is absolutely zero debate in my mind, this was a double homicide," says Canadian Sen. Linda Frum, a longtime friend of the couple, per the New York Times. The Globe and Mail reports that just days before the bodies were found, Honey Sherman was enthusiastically making plans for their annual trip to Florida, emailing friends that she would be traveling to the state on Dec. 18 and Barry Sherman would join her a week later. The couple also sent out invitations last week to a dinner party at their winter home in Palm Beach.

pred: The first round of the Egyptian parliamentary elections, which took place after the ouster of former President Hosni Mubarak, saw the Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice party emerge as the leading candidate, securing a majority of seats in the full Parliament. The Brotherhood's victory is seen as a sign of support for the country's moderate Islamist groups, including the Egyptian Bloc alliance, which includes the Free Egyptians and the social-democratic Party of the Future. The Brotherhood's campaign focused on appealing to the secularists and liberals, while the military rulers have yet to specify the formula for allocating seats among parties based on their share of the vote. The final results are expected to highlight the control of the military and the influence of the religious factions, with the Brotherhood's supporters hoping to form a coalition government to address the economic slowdown and political instability. The Egyptian Revolution of 2011, which brought down Mubarak, sparked concerns about the stability of the country's political system and the possibility of a new era of conflict. The Supreme Court's decision to bring Mubarak's case to trial is seen as a reminder of the need for accountability and the consequences of breaking the law. The prosecution argues that Mubarak was a "tyrant" responsible for implementing his son's rule, and the Brotherhood's claims of a third-party alliance and the desire for a coalition government reflect the ongoing struggle between the military and the Brotherhood. The Brotherhood's appeal to the secularists and liberals aims to prevent a further period of instability and to create a stable government, while the military's demands for retaining power and the lack of clarity in the allocation of seats in the new government are seen as challenges for the Brotherhood's prospects. The outcome of the trial and the subsequent elections will determine the composition of the new government and the extent to which the Brotherhood's grip on power is maintained.
answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.

pred: A car in a red Toyota Corolla was suspended from a telephone wire in Mendon, Massachusetts, due to a driver's quick response to a GPS unit's directions. The car was westbound on Route 4 when a GPS device provided an unexpected turn-around instruction, causing the vehicle to veer off the lane and end up suspended on the phone wire. The driver, Nabila Altahan, and her passenger were not injured in the incident, but the car lost control and ended up upside down on the wire. A witness reported seeing the driver jump out of the car as it was suspended, and both vehicles were involved in a collision with other cars on the road. The police and fire departments responded to the scene, with the state trooper investigating the cause of the accident and the fire department responding to the scene of the crash. The incident highlights the potential dangers of relying solely on GPS systems for navigation and the importance of being aware of traffic signals and lane markings in emergency situations.
answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
